desc: The technical master and heavy favorite whose only hurdle is the immense pressure of securing the one major title missing from his resume.
The sport’s newest sensation who has proven he can beat Odermatt straight-up and possesses the fearless "young gun" energy needed for the Stelvio.
A literal "King of Bormio" who knows every ice patch on this track and will be fueled by a career-defining opportunity to win gold on home soil.
The veteran tactician who excels when courses are icy and technical, making him the most reliable threat to disrupt a Swiss-Italian podium.
A model of consistency who has become a permanent fixture in the World Cup Top 5 and thrives on the high-intensity vibrations of the Italian tracks.
A rising Swiss talent with incredible gliding speed who faces the brutal challenge of simply qualifying for a spot on the four-man Swiss Olympic roster.
A "Stelvio specialist" in the making whose recent breakthrough World Cup win in Super-G proves he has the elite speed to medal in Downhill as well.
A dark horse who relies on perfect snow conditions but has the "all-or-nothing" style that can occasionally produce a podium-worthy run.
North America’s best hope, whose elite aerodynamic tuck and comfort on injected ice make him a threat if the race becomes a battle of "glide."
Carrying legendary DNA, he is a late-bloomer who has finally found the top-gear speed necessary to sneak into the medals from a late starting number.
The veteran warrior of the Italian team who has overcome major injury to find the best form of his life just in time for his home Olympics.
Often overshadowed by Odermatt, he is arguably the best "pure glider" in the world and can win any race that features long, high-speed flats.
The "Flying Finn" who has become a consistent Top-10 disruptor and represents the biggest threat to the traditional alpine powerhouses.
A big-event performer who already has a World Championship medal and the high-risk style required to master a track as punishing as the Stelvio.
The home-soil "Queen of Speed" whose only real opponent is her own tendency to push past the laws of physics.
A 41-year-old sporting miracle who is technically and mentally superior to the field on this specific track.
A powerhouse specialist who arrives with massive confidence after a 2nd place finish behind Nicol Delago in the Tarvisio Downhill last week.
The 22-year-old phenom who has won in Downhill, Super-G, and Slalom this season, making her the most dangerous young disruptor in the field.
Austria’s "Iron Lady" who provides the perfect balance of risk-management and elite speed.
Italy’s model of consistency who has been knocking on the door of the podium all winter and thrives on the high-vibration ice of the Italian tracks.
A raw power-skier who can win gold if she manages to stay "quiet" in the technical turns.
Norway’s "Attacking Viking" who recently secured 2nd place in Zauchensee and possesses the high-risk style needed to steal gold in Cortina.
The veteran "Queen of the Gliders" who remains a tactical threat on flat sections and knows exactly how to peak for a single championship race.
A veteran gliding specialist who has already found the podium this season and remains Austria’s most reliable hope for a medal behind Cornelia Hütter.
A newly-minted World Cup winner who has found peak form just weeks before the Olympics and represents Italy’s most dangerous "second option" behind Sofia Goggia.
The current red-bib holder whose fearless second runs have made him the man to beat in 2026.
The reigning king who possesses a "top gear" that no other human can match when he finds his rhythm.
A flamboyant technical genius who is one "perfect dance" away from winning Brazil’s first-ever Winter Olympic gold.
A legend of the sport who is fueled by the singular obsession of adding Olympic Slalom gold to his 100 podiums.
The surprise package of the French team who has proven that his early-season wins were no fluke.
A model of modern Norwegian efficiency who just needs to find his "killer instinct" in the final ten gates.
The Swiss master of precision who provides the most reliable "safety net" for a podium finish if others falter.
An explosive, unpredictable talent who skis every run as if his life depends on it.
The "Finnish Flash" who has transformed from a relative unknown into a legitimate medal threat in just four months.
Belgium’s historic trailblazer who has reached a new level this season with his first career podium in Gurgl and possesses the technical "touch" to secure a landmark medal for his nation.
A specialist who excels in the shadows and ice of the most difficult tracks on the circuit.
The local favorite and "icy track" specialist who will rely on his elite technical power and the energy of the home crowd in Bormio to finally secure his first Olympic podium.
A veteran big-event performer and Olympic medalist who has maintained top-15 consistency all season, waiting to pounce if the younger favorites falter under the Olympic pressure.
The reigning queen of the discipline who enters the Olympics in peak "107-win" form and remains the standard by which all others are measured.
A technical revelation who has finally unlocked the speed necessary to challenge Shiffrin for the top step of the podium.
The ultimate veteran strategist who specializes in navigating difficult courses and capitalising on the mistakes of others.
The 19-year-old phenom who has already racked up four slalom podiums this season for Albania and is the biggest threat to secure a historic first-ever medal for her adopted nation.
Germany’s versatile young star who possesses the fearless "all-or-nothing" style that translates perfectly to Olympic pressure.
A high-octane charger who just proved she can go 1-2 with Shiffrin and is finally finding the consistency to match her elite speed.
Austria’s "last woman standing" in the tech field who carries the weight of a nation after Liensberger’s season-ending injury.
A veteran specialist who remains Germany’s most reliable podium bet, having secured a 2nd place behind Shiffrin in Copper Mountain earlier this season.
The future of the sport who skis with a violent precision that can beat anyone on an icy track.
Sweden’s technical leader who excels on the steepest, iciest pitches and is a constant top-10 presence waiting for the perfect run to jump onto the podium.
The reigning Giant Slalom Olympic champion who has significantly improved her slalom form this winter, securing a strong 7th place in Flachau just last week.
The surgical master of speed who enters as the heavy favorite to claim the one gold medal that defines his era.
A veteran tactician who excels when the conditions are "brutal" and remains the primary obstacle to a Swiss sweep.
The red-hot home favorite who is riding a wave of momentum after his maiden World Cup win in Wengen last week.
The most versatile skier in the world who has transformed from a tech specialist into a legitimate Super-G powerhouse this winter.
An Austrian specialist who has finally found his peak form this January, securing his first career World Cup podium with a brilliant 2nd place in the Wengen Super-G.
A technician with a "Giant Slalom heart" who uses his superior carving ability to find time in the Stelvio's most difficult sections.
The sport’s most aggressive newcomer who possesses the raw speed to win gold if he avoids the "rookie" mistakes that have plagued his season.
A master of high-speed gliding who has remained a permanent top-10 threat throughout the season and excels when the course setting allows for long, sweeping arcs.
An aerodynamic specialist whose elite "touch" on ice makes him a threat if the race becomes a battle of technical precision.
The young Swiss sensation who solidified his Olympic medal credentials with a stunning 2nd place finish in Livigno this December.
The historic "giant-killer" of the 2026 season who shocked the world by defeating Marco Odermatt to win in Val Gardena, proving he can beat anyone on his day.
A local legend who knows every bump on the Stelvio and will be fueled by the once-in-a-lifetime chance to win an Olympic medal in his own backyard.
A French veteran known for his tactical intelligence who consistently hovers near the podium and thrives on the dark, icy conditions typical of the Stelvio.
The home-soil "Queen of Speed" who enters the Olympics with the red bib and a singular focus on home-court dominance.
A 41-year-old miracle who is using her legendary "Strahler" (gliding) ability to defy age and the laws of physics.
A fearless charger from New Zealand whose aggressive Giant Slalom turns make her a nightmare for the European favorites.
Germany’s "Swiss Army Knife" who proved she is a gold-medal threat by winning the final World Cup Super-G before the Games
A relentless French veteran who has found a new level of consistency this season, currently sitting in the World Cup Top 5 and proving she can challenge for a medal on any technical track.
The tactical genius who can win any Super-G race that rewards technical precision over raw, blind speed.
Italy’s "clutch" performer who has overcome early-season injuries to reclaim her spot as a front-runner, recently securing a Top-15 finish in Tarvisio to signal her readiness for home-court glory.
The "Shadow Queen" who consistently flies under the radar before exploding for a podium on the biggest of stages.
Austria’s most reliable speed specialist who thrives when the track is icy and the pressure is at its peak.
Norway’s "Attacking Viking" who prioritizes Super-G as her main discipline and arrives in Cortina with a reputation for taking the massive risks necessary to secure a major championship medal.
The rising American talent who just delivered a career-best 5th place finish in the Tarvisio Super-G, marking her as the ultimate dark horse entering the Olympics in peak form.
The surgical master of the discipline who is currently on a trajectory to become the greatest Giant Slalom skier in history.
Austria’s comeback king who proved in Alta Badia that he is the only man capable of beating Odermatt in a head-to-head technical battle.
A modern legend who has sacrificed everything to find the perfect setup for one last shot at Olympic GS Gold.
The flamboyant "dancing" specialist who is determined to bring Brazil its first-ever Winter Olympic medal through sheer technical brilliance.
The Swiss technician whose flawless carving ability makes him the most dangerous "second option" in the world.
A high-speed "gambler" who possesses the raw pace to win the race if he can stay on his skis for both runs.
The local hero who has finally found his Giant Slalom "touch" just in time to challenge for a medal on his home mountains.
A top Norwegian contender who just took the Slalom lead in Wengen and is hunting for his first Olympic Giant Slalom medal in 2026.
A consistent technical powerhouse for Norway, currently sitting near the top of the World Cup standings and looking to improve on his previous Olympic appearances.
America’s most creative technical skier who is consistently knocking on the door of the elite podium.
A Swiss veteran and former World Champion in combined who remains a dangerous threat in the technical Giant Slalom events for the upcoming Games.
The absolute breakout star of the season; she is holding the red bib with three dominant victories (Sölden, Tremblant, Semmering) and looks unstoppable.
Currently second in the discipline standings, she has found incredible consistency and is skiing with career-best confidence.
While currently 5th in the GS standings, her tactical genius and experience make her a perennial podium contender.
Bringing unmatched raw speed and aggression, she is a constant threat for the win but carries higher risk of DNF.
The defending Olympic champion is finding her form right on time, sitting 4th in the standings and skiing solidly.
The 2025 Globe winner has had a slower start to this season but is a dangerous veteran, especially on Italian snow.
Fresh off a runner-up finish in Sölden this season, she is a high-risk, high-reward skier who can storm the podium if she eliminates the small mistakes.
The teenage prodigy is consistently cracking the top 10 this winter (7th in the opener), making her a dangerous dark horse for a surprise medal.
Consistently knocking on the door of the top 5 and could capitalize on mistakes.
Having successfully returned from injury with a bronze medal in Mont-Tremblant this December, she is a proven winner who excels on the steep Italian pitches.
A slalom specialist whose giant slalom skills have improved enough to threaten for a surprise medal.
As the current discipline leader with the best shooting percentage in the field, she is the safest bet for this format where accuracy is king.
The defending World Champion in this event and home favorite has the perfect blend of speed and calm shooting, though pressure will be immense.
A stealthy competitor who rarely misses and currently sits high in the discipline standings.
A rising star who has climbed the World Cup standings this winter with remarkable consistency on the range.
The fastest skier on the circuit who will win gold by a minute if she shoots clean, but risks falling out of the top 10 with just a few misses.
The 2018 Olympic Champion in this specific event knows exactly how to peak for the big occasion despite a quieter season.
Her ski speed guarantees a medal contention, but she must manage her nerves on the shooting range to avoid costly penalty minutes.
A precision shooter who excels in the Individual format and has shown consistent podium form this season.
An elite all-rounder who can win any race, though her aggressive shooting style is slightly riskier in the 15km format.

The current Sprint Crystal Globe leader and most consistent biathlete of the 2025/2026 season. Her combination of a top-tier shooting percentage and clinical finishing speed makes her the gold medal benchmark.

The breakout star of the season, currently 2nd in the sprint standings. While she lacks the raw power of the French or Swedes, her ability to consistently shoot 10/10 keeps her on the podium nearly every weekend.
The winner of the most recent sprint in Ruhpolding (Jan 16, 2026). She has a legendary ability to peak for major championships and is currently back to her best form.

A true "sprint specialist" who won in Oberhof this month with a clean sheet. She is arguably the fastest skier on the circuit; if she hits 10/10, the gold is likely hers, but one standing miss can be her undoing.
The U23 sensation who has carried the Norwegian team this winter. Her aggressive skiing style is perfectly suited for the 7.5km distance.
Currently 6th in the world standings and a consistent top-6 finisher in the sprint format this year.
Though she has focused more on the long-distance Individual event this season, the home-snow advantage in Antholz-Anterselva makes her a threat if she clears the standing stage quickly.
The veteran Italian star has shown flashes of her old speed this January; a clean shooting performance in front of her home crowd could lead to a fairytale result.
A sprint world champion (2024) who thrives on the high-intensity atmosphere of the Olympic range.
A rising talent on the deep French squad who has been knocking on the door of the top 5 all season.
The reigning World Cup overall champion from last season has struggled with minor health issues this winter, but her experience makes her dangerous if she is at 100%.
The defending Sprint World Champion (2025). Her shooting has been erratic this winter (15th in sprint standings), but her skiing "engine" is so large she can medal even with a penalty.

The undisputed "Queen of the Pursuit" this season. She has won two pursuits already (including the most recent in Ruhpolding on Jan 18) and leads the overall standings. Her 90%+ shooting accuracy makes her almost impossible to shake once she takes the lead.

The most consistent "clean shooter" in the field and currently 2nd in the overall standings. She rarely gains time on the skis but moves up the leaderboard by hitting 20/20 targets while others head to the penalty loop.
Currently in peak form after a massive week in Ruhpolding (1st in Sprint, 2nd in Pursuit). She is a big-event performer who loves the tactical cat-and-mouse game of the pursuit.

The winner of the Oberhof pursuit this January. She is the fastest "chaser" in the world; even if she starts 30 seconds back, she can hunt down the leaders. Her only weakness is the final standing shoot, where high-pressure misses can cost her the gold.
A very reliable shooter who is currently 6th in the world standings; she is a "points machine" who could snag a medal if the favorites falter.
The top Norwegian this winter. She has finished 4th in recent pursuits and is the most reliable "closer" on her team, capable of a late-race surge for the bronze.
A rising star who just secured her first pursuit podium (3rd) in Ruhpolding. She is currently riding a wave of confidence and is part of the dominant French training group.
While her season started slowly due to injury, she is a master of the pursuit format. Racing in front of a home Italian crowd, her fast shooting rhythm can put immediate pressure on the leaders.
She has the speed to make up massive deficits, but the four shooting stages in a pursuit often expose her inconsistency.
A steady veteran who is consistently in the top 7. If the lead group gets into a "shooting battle," her experience allows her to stay calm and capitalize on their mistakes.
The 2024 World Champion in this event. She has the "killer instinct" needed for pursuit racing, though her shooting has been slightly more erratic this winter than in previous years.
Coming off a career-best 5th place in Ruhpolding, she is proving that she can compete with the elite when the conditions are difficult.
The current discipline leader who can win by huge margins if his range work matches his elite ski speed.
The reigning World Champion and fastest skier this season, making him the man to beat if he stays calm on the mats.
The overall World Cup leader carrying the hopes of Italy; he’s a podium lock if he survives the final standing bout.
An instinctive "artist" on skis whose lightning-fast shooting could deliver a medal or a collapse in this high-penalty format.
A model of consistency currently sitting second in the individual standings, making him a major threat for a podium.
A tactical master at altitude who has tailored his entire 2026 preparation to peak for this specific gold medal.
The world’s best shooter and defending overall champ; his 90%+ accuracy makes him a safe bet for an Olympic medal.
The veteran Italian "speedster" who could ride a wave of home-crowd energy to one final surprise career podium.
The defending champion whose experience and Olympic "clutch" factor make him dangerous despite a quieter season.
One of the fastest finishers in the world who needs a rare "clean" day on the range to grab a medal.
A steady young Frenchman who is capable of a top-10 finish if the high-altitude conditions cause the favorites to miss.

The current Sprint World Cup leader. He won the Oberhof sprint (Jan 8, 2026) and was 2nd in Ruhpolding just days ago. His ski speed is currently #1 in the world, and performing in front of his home crowd in Antholz makes him the man to beat.

The winner of the most recent sprint in Ruhpolding (Jan 17, 2026). He is a master of the "short" game and thrives in high-altitude conditions. He is high variance only because he sometimes struggles with "shaky legs" in the final standing stage.
Currently 3rd in the sprint standings. He is the fastest finisher in the field and has finished in the top 6 of every sprint this January. If he shoots 10/10, he will likely win gold.
The veteran hasn't won a sprint this year, but his experience in Olympic pressure is unmatched. He is currently 4th in the sprint standings.

The Yellow Bib holder for much of the season. While he specializes in longer distances, his raw power makes him a threat here. He finished 4th in the Annecy sprint and is looking for his first sprint podium of the year.
Coming off a massive Pursuit win in Ruhpolding (Jan 18). He is arguably the fastest "pure" skier in Norway right now. He finished 3rd in the Oberhof sprint and is in the best form of his career.
While better suited for the 20km, his 95% shooting accuracy in sprints this season (19/20) means he is always waiting to pounce if the "speedsters" miss.
A powerhouse who thrives in the heavy snow conditions often found in Antholz. He secured a brilliant 2nd place in the Oberhof sprint and remains a top-10 fixture.
The winner of the Annecy sprint this season, he is a "last-loop" specialist who can snatch a medal with his superior finishing speed even if he's trailing at the final split.
A former Sprint World Champion who remains one of the fastest skiers on the tour; he is a podium lock if he manages to keep his standing shooting under control.
Currently 5th in the sprint standings. He is the most consistent of the "New Norwegians" and has a very high floor, rarely finishing outside the top 10.
The local hero. He finished 8th in Oberhof and knows every centimeter of the Antholz track. A "fairytale" bronze in his final Olympics is not out of the question.
A relentless attacker whose aggressive skiing and rapid-fire shooting style make him the primary gold medal threat on his home tracks.
Possesses the most explosive acceleration in the field, allowing him to close gaps instantly if he can maintain composure during the standing bouts.
The ultimate tactical "chess player" who excels at pacing himself behind leaders before unleashing a powerful, decisive final lap.
A pure powerhouse whose "never-say-die" attitude and high-speed endurance make him the most dangerous closer in a sprint finish.
A heavy hitter on the skis who can skyrocket up the leaderboard provided he manages the high-altitude shooting challenges of Antholz.
When his rhythm is dialed in, he is arguably the fastest man on snow, capable of dominating the pursuit if he avoids the penalty loop.
A seasoned pursuit specialist with a legendary "clutch" factor, he knows exactly how to navigate the psychological warfare of four shooting stages.
A model of consistency and precision who relies on technical excellence to pick off rivals who buckle under the Olympic pressure.
An instinctive and unpredictable racer whose "all-or-nothing" shooting speed can either demoralize the field or lead to high-risk errors.
The clinical "surgeon" of the range; he is the most likely athlete to move from a mid-pack start to a medal through pure 20/20 accuracy.
An incredibly athletic skier who has matured into a reliable relay and pursuit threat, capable of a late-race surge into the top three.
A physical giant who thrives on tough, grinding courses where his raw strength can wear down more technical skiers.
A brilliant tactical racer with a high ceiling, he is a dark horse who consistently stays in the hunt by making smart moves in the pack.
A relentless home-track favorite who combines lightning-fast shooting with the world’s most explosive ski speed to lead the pack.
A physical powerhouse capable of breaking the field on the steep climbs, he is a gold medal threat whenever he manages his aggressive shooting rhythm.
The ultimate "tactical closer" who can lurk in the draft all race before devastating his rivals with a clinical final standing stage and a sprint finish.
Known for his unmatched "last-loop" engine, he is the most dangerous athlete to have in a lead group heading into the final kilometers.
A smart, calculated racer who excels at high altitude and knows exactly when to initiate a decisive break to avoid a crowded sprint finish.
A raw power skier who can absorb the pressure of the pack, he relies on his massive endurance to keep him in contention despite the heavy altitude.
The most composed shooter in the field; he is the specialist most likely to stay "clean" while the high-speed racers succumb to the tension of the final standing bout.
A master of precision who stays out of trouble in the pack, waiting for a "shooting war" to eliminate the favorites so his accuracy can carry him to the podium.
An instinctive and emotional racer who thrives in the head-to-head chaos, capable of a legendary performance if he finds his "flow" on the range.
A young, rising star with elite tactical awareness, he is a dark horse who has proven he can stay calm and competitive against the sport's biggest names.
A steady Swiss outsider who relies on efficient skiing and clean shooting to climb the rankings when the more aggressive favorites falter.
The local legend fueled by the home crowd; his decades of experience at Antholz make him a sentimental but very real threat for a podium in his final Games.
The newly crowned 2025/2026 World Cup overall champion. She won the season opener on this very track in Cortina and has been the most consistent pilot all winter, rarely finishing off the podium.

The world #2 who had a historic season with three World Cup wins, including a dominant gold in St. Moritz. She is arguably the best pure driver in the field, but her medal hopes depend on her push times staying competitive with the power athletes.

The defending Olympic Champion. After a slow start to her post-partum comeback season, she won the World Cup finale in Altenberg on January 17. She is the master of peaking for major championships and remains the gold medal benchmark

The 2024 World Champion and overall World Cup winner of the previous two seasons. While she finished 3rd in the standings this year, her explosive push start makes her a threat to lead any race from the first corner.
Coming off a strong 5th place in the Altenberg finale, she has found her rhythm late in the season and excels on technical tracks.
A model of consistency who finished in the top six for six out of seven races this winter, proving she is always ready to capitalize on others' mistakes.
The 2024 World Champion who started the season with a win in Innsbruck. She has the fastest start times in the world; if she nails her lines in Cortina, she is a lock for a medal.
A remarkably consistent performer who finished on the podium in St. Moritz and was the leader after the first heat in Cortina earlier this year.
One of the fastest starters in the world who has struggled with driving consistency this year but secured a season-best 5th in the final World Cup race.
The most decorated American bobsledder. She showed rising form this January with a 5th place in Sigulda and remains a threat due to her legendary start power and experience.

The defending Olympic Champions and current World Cup overall winners. They won four of the seven World Cup races this season, including the finale in Altenberg. Their combination of the world's best driving and Levi’s elite push power makes them the gold medal standard.

The most decorated pilot in history. Since her return, she has been gaining momentum, finishing the season with a silver in the Altenberg finale (Jan 18, 2026) and 2nd in the overall standings. She is a master of peaking for the Olympics, though a small mistake in Cortina's technical bottom section is her only real risk.

The 2023 World Champions and 3rd in the 2026 overall standings. They are remarkably consistent, finishing on the podium in almost every race this winter. They are "high variance" only because they often finish just fractions of a second behind their teammate Nolte.

The 2024 World Champions. They finished the season with a silver in Winterberg and 4th in the overall standings. Buckwitz is arguably the most powerful pusher among the pilots, often giving her team a massive advantage before the first corner.

A powerhouse duo that secured a silver in Innsbruck this season. Hoffman is an Olympic bronze medalist brakewoman, and Love is the reigning Monobob World Champion. If they nail their timing at the start, they have the speed to win any race.
Coming off a season-best 5th place in the final World Cup races. They have significantly improved their push times this winter and are a dark horse for a bronze if the favorites falter.

The top non-German/American threat. They finished tied for 5th in the Winterberg World Cup and are known for their extremely smooth driving lines. They are consistent podium contenders who thrive on technical tracks like Cortina.

The legendary veteran. While she spent much of the season fine-tuning her setup, her start power remains top-tier. She has medaled in four consecutive Olympics and possesses the "clutch" gene required to jump onto the podium in her fifth Games.

The dominant force of the 2025/2026 season. Lochner won six of the seven World Cup races this winter, including a victory on the Olympic track in Cortina. He is at the absolute peak of his driving powers and is the heavy gold medal favorite.

The "G.O.A.T." of bobsled and defending double Olympic Champion. While he finished 2nd in the overall standings, he remains the most technically perfect driver in history. He is "high variance" only because Lochner has consistently found more speed this season, but you can never count Friedrich out in a four-run Olympic format.

The breakout star who completed the historic German "clean sweep" of the season standings. Ammour won the 2024 European title and finished 2nd in the World Cup finale in Altenberg. He represents the future of the sport and is a lock for the podium if he maintains his world-class start times.

The top American sled and world #4. Del Duca has been remarkably consistent, finishing in the top six for nearly every race this season. He is the most likely pilot to "crash" the German party if one of the favorites makes a mistake on the technical Cortina curves.

A veteran duo that found their form late in the season with a podium finish in St. Moritz (Jan 10, 2026). Hall is a fearless driver who thrives on high-speed, technical tracks and is a major threat for bronze.
A huge surprise this winter, finishing 5th in the overall standings. They nearly medaled in the season opener in Cortina and have proven they can match the start speeds of the Europeans.

Switzerland’s top hope who secured several top-5 finishes this winter before a late-season injury scare. If fully healthy, their aerodynamic sled and smooth driving lines make them constant podium threats.

The 2025/2026 World Cup overall champion. He won the season opener on the Olympic track in Cortina and has been the most consistent pilot all winter. With a push crew that includes Georg Fleischhauer, they have the perfect balance of start power and technical driving.

The breakout star who won the final World Cup race of the season in Altenberg (Jan 18, 2026). Along with his brother Issam Ammour, he has the fastest start times in the world. If he maintains his recent form, an all-German podium sweep is a very real possibility.

The "G.O.A.T." of bobsled. Although he finished 2nd in the overall standings, he won in Winterberg this January and remains the master of the four-run Olympic format. He is "high variance" only because he has faced mechanical issues and tighter competition this year than in previous Olympic cycles.

The "Local Hero." He secured a podium in Innsbruck earlier this season and knows the Cortina track better than anyone. Fuelled by the home fans, his familiarity with the Eugenio Monti curves could propel him into the medals.

The best non-German sled in the world, finishing 4th in the overall standings. Hall is a "big-game hunter" who thrives on the world's most difficult tracks. With a fully healthy Taylor Lawrence back in the sled, they are the primary threat to break the German dominance.
Made history with Korea’s first-ever 4-man podium in the Cortina season opener. While they’ve been more erratic on European tracks, they clearly love the Olympic venue.
A model of consistency who finished the season strong with a 5th place in Altenberg. He is a veteran who rarely makes mistakes and is perfectly positioned to pounce if the favorites falter.

Switzerland’s top hope who secured a bronze in St. Moritz just two weeks ago. He is a technical specialist who finds speed in the transitions where other pilots struggle, making him a major podium threat on the Cortina ice.

The reigning World Champion and 2026 World Cup 10km Freestyle winner. She is the strongest "pure" distance skier, but after finishing 3rd behind Diggins in the Trondheim World Cup, she knows she must drop the American before the final kilometer.

The current World Cup leader and winner of the December Trondheim Skiathlon. Her ability to survive the classic leg and unleash a lethal skating sprint makes her the definitive favorite for gold in her Olympic swan song.
The silver medalist from the Trondheim World Cup. She is in her best form in years and is a specialist in high-altitude racing, making her a serious threat to spoil the US-Sweden rivalry.
The most consistent Swedish skier this January. She finished 2nd in the recent 10km Freestyle in Trondheim and has the endurance to hang with the leaders until the very end.
A wildcard who can destroy the field on her best day but struggled with positioning in Trondheim (finishing 5th). Her high-risk, high-reward style makes her a gold-or-bust contender.
The ultimate altitude specialist. She always finds an extra gear in Val di Fiemme and finished a strong 8th in the Trondheim World Cup tune-up.
A marathon expert who thrives as the race gets longer and harder. She led much of the Trondheim World Cup race and will likely try to break the pack early in Val di Fiemme.
A sprint legend who can stay with the distance pack if the pace isn't suicidal; she remains the most dangerous person to have in a 100m dash to the line.
The breakout Swiss talent who has been a top-10 regular this winter and excels on technical, hilly courses.

The undisputed queen of the 10km Freestyle. She is the reigning World Champion in this event and has won nearly every major individual freestyle race this season. In an interval start where she can "hunt" the times of others, she is the clear gold medal favorite.
A revelation in freestyle this year; she finished 2nd in the Trondheim 10km Freestyle (Dec 2025) and has become the most consistent skater on the deep Swedish team.

While she is world-class in both techniques, she is often slightly more vulnerable in pure skating compared to Diggins. However, her high-altitude engine is so massive that she remains a lock for a medal and the biggest threat to Diggins' gold.

The breakthrough star of the winter who shocked the field by winning the Alpe Cermis Final Climb and the Davos 10km Freestyle, making her Norway’s premier gold medal threat in the skating interval start.
Primarily known for her endurance, she has improved her skating significantly and could use her massive engine to snag a bronze if the conditions are slow and heavy.
A specialist on the hilly Val di Fiemme tracks. She excels at skating on steep terrain, which is exactly what the Olympic course offers.
