A cornerstone of the deep French squad who enters the Games as a legitimate spoiler threat after a very consistent January campaign.
The world’s number one who combines elite equipment with a flaw-free driving style; she is the clear "Gold to lose" favorite heading into February.
An American veteran who is having a career-year, proving in Sigulda that she can beat the Germans head-to-head on the most technical tracks in the world.
The current World Cup leader who has stepped up to lead the Austrian team and remains the most consistent podium threat outside of Germany and the USA.

The youngest of the German "Super Team." She won back-to-back Golds in Oberhof earlier this month and is currently 3rd in the world. She is a home-track specialist who is still learning to translate that speed to the ice in Italy.

After years of "4th place" finishes, she finally broke through with her first World Cup medals this season in Park City and Lake Placid. She is currently the fastest American on the lower half of the track.
A rising Italian star who enters her home Olympics with the momentum of multiple World Cup podiums this season, proving she can challenge the world's elite on any given day.
Currently 4th in the World Cup standings. She won the season opener in Winterberg and provides the Austrians with a secondary medal threat behind Schulte.
Switzerland’s lone elite slider. She sits 6th in the world and has multiple top-5 finishes this winter. She is a veteran who thrives on the icy, European tracks like the one in Cortina.
The world-beating Austrian pair whose consistency and "cool under pressure" attitude make them the favorites to become the first-ever Olympic champions in this discipline.

Currently 2nd in the world standings. Eitberger, a legendary singles medalist, has transitioned perfectly to doubles. They are the fastest starters in the field and have finished on the podium in nearly every race this January.
The trailblazing American duo who possess the "start power" necessary to lead an Olympic final from the very first curve.
Italy’s premier doubles team whose intimate knowledge of the home track and recent Nations Cup victory make them a sentimental and statistical favorite for a medal.
Latvia’s podium hopefuls who possess the championship pedigree and "Big Final" experience to challenge for a top-5 finish or better in Italy.
The backbone of the Polish luge team whose qualification ensures Poland will also be a contender in the Team Relay, where their synchronization is among the most reliable in the mid-pack.
The world’s current #1 who is entering the Olympics with the momentum of a European title and a nearly perfect equipment setup.
The greatest of all time still in the prime of his power; he is the emotional and statistical anchor of the German team.
A powerhouse who possesses the highest top-end speed in the world; he is the most likely athlete to post the fastest single run of the Olympic tournament.
The 2018 Olympic Champion. While he hasn't won a race in 2026 yet, he is a "Big Game" slider who knows exactly how to prepare for the one-off intensity of the Olympics.

Latvia’s top medal hope. He took Silver in Winterberg earlier this season and is consistently ranked in the top 5. He thrives on technical, high-G-force tracks and is widely expected to give Latvia its first individual men's luge medal.
The Beijing 2022 Silver medalist. He remains a master of aerodynamics and technical driving. He has multiple podiums this winter and provides the Austrians with a "Plan B" if Müller falters.
The six-time Olympic gold medalists who are currently rewriting the record books; they enter Italy as the definitive favorites for a fourth consecutive doubles title.

Latvia’s premier duo and the current World #3. They are the masters of technical tracks and took Silver in Sigulda earlier this winter. They are consistently on the podium and represent the biggest threat to a German-Austrian sweep.

The "Super-Sled." Kindl (a world champion singles slider) and Steu (an elite doubles driver) joined forces specifically for 2026. They took Silver in Winterberg and are currently 6th in the world despite a slow start. Their ceiling is incredibly high; when they hit their lines, they are the only pair that can match Wendl/Arlt’s speed.

The "new" Eggert pairing. After his long-time partner Sascha Benecken retired, Eggert returned with Müller and proved they are still elite by taking Silver in Oberhof (Jan 18). They are currently 4th in the world and are hunting for Germany's second Olympic spot.
The young Austrian powerhouses who represent the greatest threat to German dominance if the track conditions are fast and icy.
One of the favorite for Gold; he has replaced Riiber as the most consistent force on the World Cup and currently holds a 150-point lead in the standings.
The fastest man on skis in the discipline; his Olympic fate will be decided entirely by his performance on the Normal Hill jump.
Germany’s top hope who relies on a punishing cross-country pace to break his opponents in the final kilometer.

The "older brother" who has transformed from a top-20 regular into a consistent podium finisher this January; he and Jens have now shared a World Cup podium twice this month, signaling that the "Oftebro Double" is a very real possibility for Milano-Cortina.

The veteran legend who is having a massive resurgence. He took Silver in the Otepää Gundersen two weeks ago and sits 6th in the world. His experience in Olympic pressure-cooker situations is unmatched.
The "Flight King" who will likely lead the race for the first 7.5km before the heavy hitters like Lamparter and Schmid attempt to hunt him down.

Currently 8th in the world. He is a more balanced version of his brother, often finishing in the top 5. He provides Austria with incredible tactical depth for the "team-style" tactics often used to block the Germans.
A perennial podium threat who finally found his form with a Bronze in Ruka. He is a "pure" cross-country specialist who needs a windy day on the hill to stay in contention.
Currently 12th in the world standings. He is a very strong jumper who has been knocking on the door of a major podium all January.
The defending Olympic champion. While he has struggled with minor injuries this winter (currently 10th in the world), he remains the most dangerous sprinter in the sport.
The gold standard of the 500m; she enters the Olympics as the three-time reigning World Champion and the world record holder.
The leader of the 2025-26 World Tour who has proven she has the top-end speed to beat Velzeboer head-to-head.
America’s best hope for a sprint medal; she has been the most consistent non-Dutch skater on the World Tour podium this winter.
Canada’s most decorated short track star; her experience in two previous Olympics gives her a psychological edge in the high-pressure 500m rounds.
America’s #1 who enters Milan as the overall world #1; she is the most complete skater in the field and the biggest threat to a Dutch sweep.
The most legendary active skater in the world; she is using the 2025-26 season to prove she can win the one Olympic individual gold that has eluded her.
The model of Dutch consistency; she provides the Netherlands with a "second hammer" that makes it almost impossible for other nations to sweep the podium.
A start-speed specialist who is currently in the best form of her life, proving last week in Tilburg that she can skate sub-42.1 consistently.
Canada’s first-ever overall World Tour champion; she enters Milan as the most mentally tough skater in the field, having won five golds across the 2025-26 circuit.
Belgium’s lone star who proved in Poland that she can beat Sarault and the Americans on her day.

Currently ranked World #3 in the 1000m, Stoddard is the most consistent podium threat for the USA, having earned silver and bronze medals on the World Tour this season while narrowing the gap for the Crystal Globe.
The world’s best all-around skater right now; her recent double-gold at the European Championships has silenced any doubts about her 1000m stamina.
The veteran who is "experimenting with strategies" this winter; her silver in Montreal showed she is still the tactical benchmark for the entire field.
As the World #2 and 1500m leader, she uses her unmatched endurance to execute patient, late-race surges that have secured her 1000m gold and silver in Montreal and Dordrecht this winter.

Canada's high-energy wildcard has proven she can challenge the elite with a 4th-place finish in Gdansk, though her podium chances depend on tempering her aggressive passing style to stay out of the penalty box.

Italy’s rising star and reigning 1500m European Champion is a dangerous long-shot on home ice, coming off a strong 5th-place finish in Dordrecht and an A-Final appearance at the 2025 World Championships.
Proved last week in Tilburg that she is now a top-tier 1000m threat, nearly pipping her sister at the finish line.
The gold medal favorite; she has won four 1500m golds this season and enters Milan with the most reliable "kick" in the sport.
Canada’s first-ever overall Crystal Globe winner; she has the highest "ceiling" in the field and enters Milan with 9 individual medals from the 2025/26 tour.
The tactical GOAT; her out-course overtaking in Montreal was described by the ISU as "another master class," signaling she is ready for a third straight Olympic 1500m medal.
The world leader in laps led; she is the most physically resilient skater in the 1500m and is expected to be the one dictating the pace in the Olympic final.
The "Home Ice" factor; she has reached every 1500m A-Final this season and has the benefit of training on the Olympic ice for years.
Belgium’s engine; she is currently the world leader in 1500m points and the only skater who has shown the strength to beat Kim Gil-li in a head-to-head sprint.
America’s best hope for individual gold; her tactical flexibility allows her to adapt to any pace, from a slow crawl to a world-record-pace grind.
Coming off her European title last week, she is the "emotional 5-star" of the 2026 Games; her experience and home-ice advantage make her the most dangerous veteran in the field.
The man to beat. He has 8 total World Tour golds this season across all distances and is currently the most dominant force the sport has seen since the peak of Charles Hamelin.
The "Prince of Milan." Every podium he has taken this year has been a statement that he is ready to defend his home ice against the North American surge.
Coming off his European hat-trick, he is the "hottest" skater in the world right now and the primary disruptor of the Canadian dominance.
The surprise winner of the Dordrecht World Tour 500m (Nov 29, 2025). He proved he can beat the best in the world on a technical track and represents America's best hope for a sprint medal.
The winner of the Milan Test Event last year. He has proven he loves the ice in the Olympic venue and currently sits 4th in the overall world rankings.
The "Italian Gladiator" is a heavy favorite on home ice after breaking his World Tour gold drought with a massive 1000m victory in Montreal this season.
The 18-year-old "White Tiger" has stunned the world as the 2026 breakout star, having already claimed 1000m gold in Dordrecht and silver in Montreal.
The 2025 World Champion at this distance remains a top-tier threat who uses his explosive speed to consistently reach the A-Final, despite a "high variance" season filled with photo finishes.
The Olympic legend is finding his best form just in time for Milan, recently securing a 1000m silver in Dordrecht by navigating traffic with his trademark technical precision.
The overall Crystal Globe leader is the most physically dominant skater in the field, though he is slightly more vulnerable in the 1000m than in his "guaranteed" 1500m and 500m events.
Fresh off a historic triple-gold sweep at the 2026 European Championships (Jan 18), the Dutchman is the hottest skater in Europe and a clear threat to the global podium.
The veteran "elder statesman" of the Korean team remains a tactical master who can still pull off a podium, as proven by his bronze medal at the Montreal World Tour stop.
A consistent A-Finalist and 2025 World Championship medalist, Sun Long is China's most reliable middle-distance anchor heading into the Games.
Latvia's lone star is the ultimate "dark horse" who consistently finishes in the top 6 and possesses the raw speed to capitalize on any chaos at the front of the pack.
The undisputed World #1 and overall Crystal Globe leader enters Milan as a 5-star favorite after winning the 1500m gold in Gdansk and dominating the distance all winter.
Italy's breakout star of 2026 proved he is a legitimate medal threat by taking a stunning Silver in Gdansk, finishing just 0.06 seconds behind Dandjinou.
The hottest skater in Europe right now, he is a major podium threat after winning the 2026 European 1500m title in Tilburg just last week (Jan 17).
A core member of Canada’s "Crystal Globe" squad, Roussel is a tactical powerhouse who recently beat Dandjinou at the Canadian Championships and consistently reaches the 1500m A-Finals.
Japan's top middle-distance specialist has been a model of consistency this season, highlighted by a career-best Silver medal in Montreal and a 4th-place finish in Gdansk.
China’s most reliable endurance skater, Sun Long secured Bronze at the World Tour opener and remains a constant threat to the podium with his patient, late-race surges.
The "Prince of Milan" is a 1500m force who took Bronze in Gdansk and will be the sentimental favorite to lead an Italian podium sweep on home ice.
The 18-year-old phenom shocked the world by winning Gold in his 1500m World Tour debut in Montreal, signaling the arrival of South Korea's next great superstar.
The defending Olympic 1500m silver medalist is a "big race" specialist who currently sits 3rd in the overall world standings and possesses the world's most dangerous final-lap kick.
Latvia's technical master continues to overachieve against the big nations, coming off a strong 5th-place finish in Gdansk that puts him on the cusp of his first major 1500m podium.
The new queen of the sport; her 2026 Crystal Globe win makes her the most reliable bet for a medal in Milan.
Germany's top hope; her win on the Olympic track in Cortina three months ago makes her the tactical benchmark for the field.
The veteran legend enters the final Olympic stretch in blistering form, having reclaimed the World Cup overall lead on January 2nd with a dominant second season victory in Winterberg.
The "Human Slingshot"; her start times are so much faster than the rest of the field that she often starts the drive with a 0.15-second advantage.

The reigning 2025 World Champion and Beijing bronze medalist remains the technical benchmark of the field, though her 2026 season has been a battle of consistency as she aims to peak for the four-run Olympic marathon.

The 2025 World Bronze medalist has carried her resurgence into the Olympic year, recently securing a calm and clinical Bronze in Winterberg (Jan 2, 2026) to cement her status as a top-five world threat.
The defending champ; she is currently ranked lower than her teammates but has the mental fortitude to deliver under Olympic pressure.
The prodigy; she is looking to become the youngest Olympic skeleton champion in history and has the world titles to prove she can do it.
The "King of the Sled"; he enters Milan having won nearly 75% of the races he entered this season.
The 2024 European Champion enters Milan in peak form after finishing World #3 overall and winning the 2025/26 season finale in Altenberg with a record-setting performance.
he world's fastest starter; he will likely lead after the first 50 meters of every heat, forcing the Europeans to chase him down the track.

The Beijing 2022 silver medalist remains Germany's most consistent veteran threat, having secured an overall World #4 ranking after finishing the season with a dramatic three-way tie for silver in Altenberg.

The reigning European Champion has established himself as a 2026 medal favorite by finishing World #5 overall and proving his mastery of the Olympic track with a silver medal at the Cortina season opener.
South Korea’s top star successfully returned from a back injury to finish World #6 this season, highlighted by a bronze in Lillehammer and a strong 5th-place finish at the Cortina Olympic test event.
The big-game hunter; despite a lower world ranking (9th), his recent silver in Altenberg proves he has fixed his equipment issues just in time for his title defense.
The "Cortina Specialist"; he is the only non-British/German slider to have consistently reached the podium in the final month of the season.
The "Slovenian Sensation"; she has 28 career wins at age 20 and is the only jumper who has won on every type of hill this season.

Currently World #2 overall. After years of injury struggles, she has become the most consistent Large Hill threat to Prevc, frequently finishing in the top 3 this winter. She is "high variance" only because her telemark landings can be inconsistent under high pressure.
The "comeback queen" who has surged into the World Top 4. She is a Large Hill specialist who thrives on the bigger, faster jumps and consistently pushes for the podium in the 130m+ range.
Canada’s new "Air Ace"; her win in Oberstdorf three weeks ago proved she can beat Prevc head-to-head on a Large Hill.
Carrying the weight of Austria's podium hopes; she has transitioned from a supporting jumper to a consistent world-class leader this winter.
Germany's top-ranked jumper (World #5). She enters Milan on the back of three consecutive podium finishes in January. She has a high-risk, high-reward style that makes her a major threat for a medal.

After years of battling injuries and fighting for a spot on the deep German roster, she is finally in the best form of her career; she is now Germany's "third ace" and a crucial part of their hunt for a Team Gold.
The "New Year's Surprise"; her silver in Germany has made her the dark horse that every top team is now watching closely.
The all-time wins leader. She is still a force on the Large Hill (ranked World #8) and remains the most experienced jumper in the field.
The "Gold Standard"; she hasn't finished outside the top 2 in a Normal Hill event for over two months and enters Milan as the reigning World Champion.
Austria's new lead; she has narrowed the gap to Prevc significantly in January and is currently the world leader in "style points" for her landings.

Currently ranked World #2 overall. She is the technical master of the Japanese squad and thrives on Normal Hills, where her explosive take-off provides a significant advantage. She took Bronze in Zao (Jan 21) and is a constant presence on the podium.

The 2025 World Silver medalist. She has struggled with consistency in January, but her "ceiling" is incredibly high; if she clicks on the training jumps in Milan, she moves immediately into the 4-star category.

While she prefers the Large Hill (where she won Silver in Sapporo today, Jan 24), Strate took Bronze on the Normal Hill in Zao this week. She is Canada's only medal hope following the injury to Alexandria Loutitt.

The 2025 World Bronze medalist. Strøm has been the anchor for Norway this season, consistently finishing in the 4th-6th range. She is a powerhouse on the Normal Hill and is arguably the best "bad weather" jumper in the top tier.
The "January Surprise"; she has transitioned from a team-event specialist to a genuine individual medal threat in the last three weeks.
The breakout star of the season who shocked the field with a Silver in Oberstdorf. While better on larger hills, her confidence is at an all-time high.
The "Olympic Legend"; she is looking to finally upgrade her two silvers to a gold in what is likely her final Games.
The "Flight King"; following in his sister Nika's footsteps, he is looking to complete a historic family double-gold in Milan.
The "Defending King"; he is purely focused on his own performance and has the rare ability to find an extra 2 meters of distance when the pressure is highest.

The breakout star of the Austrian team and current World #4. He finished as the runner-up in the Four Hills Tournament and has become the most consistent Normal Hill jumper in Europe. His technical precision on the take-off is currently unmatched.

The "Comeback King"; despite the controversy that stripped him of a World silver last year, his Normal Hill World Gold from 2025 confirms that when his equipment is legal, he is arguably the most precise jumper in the field.
The "Silent Threat"; his technical consistency in January has proven that Japan has a second legitimate gold medal threat.
The 2024/25 overall champion. While he has had a quieter season (World #6), his win in Bischofshofen on January 6 proved he still has the "winning touch" required for a major medal.

The 19-year-old known as "Bambi." He nearly won the Innsbruck World Cup this month (finishing 3rd) and represents the next generation of Austrian stars who could steal a medal with a fearless performance.
Germany’s top-performing jumper in January. He surprised the field with an opening podium at the Four Hills and currently sits 9th in the world. He is the "form" pick for the German squad.

Currently World #5 and the 2025 World Silver medalist. He is part of the "Slovenian Wall" that has dominated the podium this year. His style is built for the smaller Normal Hill where technical style points are the deciding factor.
The "G.O.A.T."; he is looking for his first individual Olympic gold to complete the "Grand Slam" of ski jumping titles.
The "Eagle of Slovenia"; he has won seven times this season and enters Milan looking to become the first man to win individual gold while his sister (Nika) does the same.

The overall runner-up of the Four Hills Tournament and current World #4. He has proven himself as the most consistent Large Hill jumper in the Austrian squad, possessing a technical "glide" that keeps him in the top 3 regardless of the hill profile.
The "Japanese King"; he is rounding into his best form in January and currently leads the world in average jump distance over the last three weeks.

The World #5 and a former Large Hill World Tour leader. He recently won the Large Hill event in Falun and provides Slovenia with a "double-threat" alongside Prevc. His flight style is incredibly aesthetic and consistently earns high style points from judges.
The "Silent Killer"; his rise to World #3 has been the biggest shock of the season, and he currently has the best landing-success rate in the field.
Germany’s top-ranked jumper (World #7). He set a hill record earlier this season and has three Large Hill podiums, making him the most dangerous wildcard in the German team.

The "German Revelation"; after years as a continental cup regular, he has suddenly become Germany’s most consistent Large Hill flyer, and if he arrives in Milan at 100% health, he is the most likely German to sneak onto the individual podium.
The World #6 and winner of the Bischofshofen World Cup finale (Jan 6). He is a pure Large Hill specialist who generates more lift off the table than almost anyone else in the top 10.
The 19-year-old "Prodigy" who finished 3rd overall in the Four Hills. He is fearless on the 140m jumps and represents the biggest youth threat to the established veterans.
The gold standard; she has won nearly every sprint she has entered in the last two years and is the most complete athlete in the sport's history.
The "Swiss Rocket"; she is the world's fastest "booter," often making up 5–10 seconds on the hiking section alone.
The "Silent Threat"; she has beaten Harrop twice this winter, proving that the French team has two legitimate candidates for the top step of the podium.
The "Local Hero"; she will have the support of the entire Bormio valley, and her technical descent on the Stelvio slope is considered the best in the field.
The 2025 World Bronze medalist. Paller is a "bracket racer" who excels in the head-to-head format of the semi-finals and finals.

The "Transition Queen"; while she lacks the raw uphill engine of Emily Harrop, her background as a world-class trail runner and her history of winning major titles on home snow makes her the primary candidate to steal a medal if any of the "Big Three" falter.

A veteran superstar who was the overall World #3 before a cycling accident in October 2025. She has made a "miracle recovery" to join the Spanish Olympic team this month; while her fitness is a question mark, her race craft is world-class.
The "Gold Standard"; he has won the last three World Cup sprints he entered and is currently the fastest transitioner in Olympic history.
The "French Anchor"; he is the reigning overall world #1 and is looking for a sprint medal to cement his legacy as the greatest of his generation.
Switzerland’s "Young Gun"; he has the highest uphill speed in the world right now and is the only man to beat Cardona Coll this winter.

A legendary sprinter and former world #1. While he has taken a "backseat" to his teammate Kistler this season, he still secured Silver in Solitude and Bronze in Bormio. He is a "Big Game" player who rarely misses an Olympic-sized podium.
The "Catalan Rocket"; he is the most successful youth athlete in Spanish history and is currently the highest-ranked U23 sprinter on the global circuit.

The most dangerous wildcard in the field. Currently World #3, he has been a podium fixture all season. He represents Belgium’s best-ever chance for a Winter Olympic gold, possessing a massive engine and a fearless descending style.
The "French Relay Ace"; he has transitioned from a vertical specialist to one of the most technical sprinters in the French stable, known for having the fastest "skin-to-ski" transitions in January.
The "Golden Boy" of Canada; he is looking to upgrade his Beijing silver to gold and is currently the most feared rider in every qualifying heat.
The "Aussie Powerhouse"; he enters Milan as the world #1 and the most physically dominant rider on the jumps.
The "French Prodigy"; at just 18, he has the fastest reaction time out of the starting gate in the entire FIS circuit.

The man in the hottest form. Dusek won the Gold in China (Jan 18) and sits third in the overall standings. He has become Austria's premier threat, showing a rare ability to navigate "traffic" and make passes in the final three turns.
The "Tactician"; he knows exactly how to win an Olympic final, and his lower ranking only makes him a more dangerous "under-the-radar" threat.

The "Precision Rider"; he is known for having the most stable board-control in the "Negative G" sections of the Livigno course. He currently has more top-5 finishes in 2025/26 than any other Frenchman.
Italy's best hope for home gold. Ranked World #6, Sommariva has three podiums this season. He will have the "Livigno Advantage," having spent hundreds of hours training on this specific Italian snow.
The "Consistency King"; he is the most experienced rider on the team and has a rare 100% success rate in advancing from the qualifying rounds this season.
The breakout American who sits 8th in the world. He took his first career podium last month and is the U.S. team's best hope for an individual medal.
Currently World #9 and the top German prospect. He has a very high "basketball IQ" on the snow, finding gaps where others see walls.
The "Phoenix"; her return from a career-threatening injury to win in China last week has made her the sentimental and statistical favorite for Milan.

The 2022 Silver medalist and current World #2. Trespeuch is the anchor of the French "powerhouse" squad. She took Bronze in China last week and has been on the podium in almost every race this winter. She is "high variance" only because she occasionally gets caught in "mid-pack" traffic, but her ability to pass in the final turn is the best in the business.
The "Yellow Bib"; she is the most consistent rider of 2026 so far, possessing a massive mental edge over the veteran field.

The sensation of the early season. Casta won the opening World Cup in Cervinia (Dec 13) but suffered a high-speed crash in China last week that dropped her in the standings. If she is fully recovered by February 6, her raw "gate-to-first-turn" speed makes her a podium lock.
The "Livigno Legend"; she is treating these Games as her career finale and will have the most vocal home support of any athlete in Italy.
The "Dongbeiya Champion"; her victory in China last week was a statement to the world that she is ready to upgrade her 2018 silver to a 2026 gold.
The "Australian Prodigy"; at just 21, she is the youngest rider in the World Top 10 and enters her first Olympics with three World Cup podiums already on her resume from the last 12 months.

Formerly Samková. The 2014 Olympic Champion is still one of the most stylish and technically sound riders in the world. While she missed the Big Final in China, she remains a tactical genius who can out-maneuver younger riders in heavy traffic.
Switzerland’s top hope. She has been a consistent "Small Final" winner this year and is currently World #10. She is known for her aggressive starts and could easily sneak into the Big Final.
The "American Anchor"; with Lindsey Jacobellis out, Gaskill has stepped up as the leader of the U.S. team, possessing some of the fastest qualifying times on the circuit this winter.

Italy's primary gold medal hope. She won the season opener in Mylin and has been a podium fixture throughout the winter. As the hometown favorite, she has spent more time training on the specific "crystalline" snow of the Italian Alps than anyone else.
The "Japanese Ace"; she has the most consistent results of 2026, never finishing outside the top 3 in any major event this winter.
The "Triple Threat"; she is the only woman with the "Triple Cork 1440" in her arsenal. If she lands it in Livigno, the gold is hers; if she doesn't, Brookes and Murase are ready to pounce.
The "British Phenom"; her 96.33 at X Games is the highest score recorded in competition this season. She arrives in Milan as the favorite to take Britain's first-ever snowboard gold.

Canada’s most consistent veteran. She officially qualified for her third Olympics last week (Jan 16) and finished 7th at the X Games. She has the "clutch" gene necessary to steal a medal if the top three falter.

The 16-year-old "Rookie Sensation." She stunned the field by taking Silver at the Laax Open (Jan 18) in her debut season. While she finished 9th at X Games, her raw talent and fearlessness make her the most dangerous wildcard in the US squad.

The legendary two-time Big Air Olympic Champion. At 34, she is on her "Farewell Tour" and recently took Bronze at the Laax Open. While Slopestyle is her "secondary" event, her air awareness and consistency make her a constant podium threat.

The 2022 Olympic Bronze medalist. Coady finished 4th at the X Games last week with a 86.00 and has been a permanent fixture in the top 5 all season. She is a "Big Event" specialist who knows how to craft a run for maximum style points.

The current undisputed queen of Big Air. Two days ago (Jan 24, 2026), she won the X Games Big Air Gold and made history as the first woman to land a Triple Cork 1620 in competition. She is currently the highest-ranked woman in the world and has the most technical run in history.

Fresh off her Slopestyle gold at X Games, Brookes took Bronze in Big Air this weekend. She is the reigning World Champion and possesses a unique "flat-spin" style that judges adore. She is high variance only because she often attempts her most difficult trick (Cab 1440) on her final hit.

While she focuses more on Slopestyle, she is the only woman who can match Murase's amplitude. She skipped the X Games Big Air final to rest her knee, but if she’s 100% in Milan, she’s a 5-star threat.

The 17-year-old sensation. She enters the Olympics as the World Cup Leader after winning three consecutive events this winter (Secret Garden, Copper Mountain, and Laax Open). She is the only rider currently pushing Chloe Kim’s technical difficulty, often opening her runs with a switch backside 720 that sets her apart from the Japanese field.

Another 16-year-old prodigy. She took Silver at the X Games last week and Silver at the Laax Open (Jan 17). She is currently World #2 in the standings. She represents the new wave of Japanese riders who treat the 22-foot pipe like a trampoline, specializing in technical "alley-oop" tricks.
Canada’s top hope. She won the Calgary World Cup earlier this season and sits World #3. She is exceptionally strong in icy conditions, which could be a factor in the night-time final in Livigno.

The two-time defending Olympic Champion. Kim secured her spot for Milan by winning her third World Title in March 2025 and has been peerless since her return. While she occasionally skips World Cups to manage her health, she is the only woman consistently landing Frontside and Cab 1080s with massive amplitude. She is the "low variance" pick because, even with a safe run, she remains 5 points ahead of the field.

The woman with the most momentum. Just three days ago (Jan 23, 2026), she won X Games Gold in Aspen with a 95.33. She also took Silver at the 2025 World Championships. She is "high variance" because she often prioritizes riskier 1080s that lead to falls, but if she stomps her run like she did in Aspen, she is the only person who can realistically take Gold from Kim or Choi.
The Beijing Silver medalist. At 36, she took Bronze at the X Games last week, proving she still has the amplitude to compete with the 16-year-olds.

The veteran legend. At 32, she is heading into her fifth Olympics. She took Bronze at the Laax Open and remains the world leader in "style" and grab execution. While she lacks the 1080-triple combinations of the teenagers, her "cleanliness" always keeps her in the medal hunt.

The two-time Crystal Globe winner. She won the Aspen World Cup (Jan 9, 2026) with a flawless 91.00. She is the most consistent "technical" rider in Japan’s deep squad, rarely missing a podium but sometimes lacking the "wow factor" amplitude of the top two.

The comeback story of the year. After nearly a decade away from the sport, she took Silver at the Aspen World Cup (Jan 9). She has a high-amplitude, "old-school" style that judges are rewarding this season.

The defending Olympic Big Air champion and Slopestyle silver medalist. Su has been the most consistent rider of the 2025/26 season, taking Silver in Aspen (Jan 10) and Bronze at the Laax Open (Jan 18). He has the highest amplitude in the field, but he is "high variance" because he often pushes for a 1980 on the final jump which carries a high crash risk.

The "G.O.A.T." just made a massive statement. Yesterday (Jan 25, 2026), McMorris won X Games Gold with a near-perfect score of 96.33, securing his 25th career X Games medal. Despite being 32, his technical rail precision and "clutch" factor on his final run make him the most reliable podium bet in the sport. He is seeking a historic fourth consecutive Olympic slopestyle medal.

The breakout star of 2026. On January 18, he made history by becoming the first Frenchman to win a Slopestyle World Cup (Laax Open). His run, featuring a unique backside 1080 pullback to 900, has redefined "style" scores this year. He enters Milan with massive momentum.
The 17-year-old who took Silver at the Laax Open last week. He is the leader of a Japanese squad that specializes in "flat-spin" rotations that the judges are heavily rewarding this season.

The winner of the Aspen World Cup (Jan 10, 2026). After a year of suspension, he has returned with a vengeance. He is currently the highest-ranked American and thrives on high-pressure "Big Final" environments.

The "Local Hero." He secured his Olympic qualification with a 6th place in Laax. On European snow, he is known for being incredibly consistent and could sneak onto the podium if the top favorites fall.

The defending Olympic Champion and the newly crowned 2025/26 Big Air Crystal Globe winner. Su won back-to-back World Cups in November and December (Chongli and Beijing) with a staggering 181.00 points. He is the most technically consistent rider in the world, combining "clean" 1980s with perfect execution scores. He skipped the final World Cup to focus on his "secret" Olympic run.
Currently ranked World #2 overall. He took Bronze at the X Games yesterday and pushed Ogiwara to the limit in Steamboat. He is the most reliable "podium insurance" for the Japanese team.

The man who just broke the sport. Two days ago (Jan 24, 2026), Ogiwara won X Games Gold by stomping a 2340 (six and a half rotations). He also won the Steamboat World Cup last month. He is "high variance" because he regularly crashes on his first two attempts, but if he lands the 2340 in Milan, the gold medal is likely his by a 10-point margin.

The breakout American of 2026. He took Bronze in the Steamboat World Cup and finished 2nd at the 2025 World Championships. He is a specialist in the "Frontside Triple 1620" and represents the U.S. team's best chance at a Big Air medal.
A veteran favorite who took Bronze in the Beijing World Cup last month. He doesn't have the 2340, but his "Style" scores are consistently 5–10 points higher than the tech-focused riders.
The home-crowd favorite. Currently World #5, he has been knocking on the door of a major podium all winter and will be boosted by the local fans in Livigno.

The surprise Silver Medalist at the X Games (yesterday). Jamieson has mastered the 2160 tail grab, a trick that separates the "Big Final" riders from the rest. He is in peak form heading into Italy and has become New Zealand's top hope for a medal.

The 18-year-old Canadian superstar. He has officially qualified for the Olympic team and possesses the "Triple Moose Flip," a trick no one else in the field can replicate. Bouchard won the Aspen Big Air earlier this month and is currently the most creative threat to the Japanese/Chinese dominance.
The "Backside Specialist"; he is currently on a two-month undefeated streak and has the highest technical "difficulty" score ever recorded in the sport.
The "Triple Cork King"; he is the only man who has landed a Frontside Triple Cork 1440 in every final he has entered this winter.

Currently World #6 and a former Crystal Globe winner. He took Bronze at the Secret Garden World Cup and recently landed a switch backside double cork 1440—a trick once exclusive to Scotty James. He represents Japan's "insurance policy" for a medal.

The most versatile rider in the world. Currently World #2 overall, he won the Calgary World Cup (Jan 3) and has multiple podiums this winter. Guseli is known for having the highest average amplitude (height) in the pipe. If he hits his "victory lap" run in Milan, he could easily steal the Gold.
The veteran took Bronze in Calgary this month and remains a podium threat in difficult, icy conditions.
The top American hope. While the U.S. men's team has struggled in the post-Shaun White era, Josey’s technical switch-riding keeps him in the mix for a small final or a surprise podium.

The "Record Shatterer." On November 16, 2025, in Salt Lake City, Kok broke the 12-year-old World Record with a time of 36.09. She arrives in Milan as a three-time consecutive World Champion and the winner of seven straight World Cup 500m races earlier this season. She has no technical weaknesses right now and is the only skater consistently dipping into the low 36s.

The Defending Olympic Gold Medalist. Jackson officially punched her ticket to Milan on Jan 6, 2026, at the U.S. Trials. While she took silver in the Salt Lake World Cup with a personal best of 36.57, she has battled a hamstring injury and minor health issues throughout December. She is "high variance" because she is currently recovering her top-end speed, but her championship experience makes her the primary threat to the Dutch.
A veteran who is having a career-best season. She beat Kim Min-sun for silver in Norway last month and has established herself as Poland's strongest medal hope.

The top Japanese sprinter. She has consistently hovered around the podium all winter, including a Bronze in Salt Lake City and a Silver in Hamar. She has the fastest opening 100m in the field, which is vital for the Milano ice.

Although the 1000m is her signature, Leerdam has become a permanent 500m podium threat this season, finishing 2nd to Kok in several World Cups. She is the strongest "finisher" in the world, often making up huge ground in the final 200 meters.

The 2022-23 dominant force. After a sluggish start to the 2025/26 season (finishing 17th in early rounds), she has found her form, taking Bronze at the Hamar World Cup (Dec 15, 2025). She is a "Big Event" skater who is peaking at exactly the right time.

Having her best 1000m season ever. She pushed Leerdam to a photo finish in Salt Lake City (losing by just 0.08s) and took Silver in Hamar last month. While the 500m is her primary focus, her increased endurance has made her a legitimate threat to win double gold in Milan.

The "Gold Standard." Despite a dramatic fall at the Dutch Olympic Trials on Dec 26, the national committee officially selected her for the team on Jan 1, 2026, citing her total dominance of the World Cup season. She won both the Salt Lake City and Heerenveen 1000m events, posting a world-best time of 1:12.35. Her "low variance" status comes from her unrivaled finishing lap; she is consistently 0.3 to 0.5 seconds faster than the field in the final 400 meters.

The Defending Olympic Gold Medalist. Takagi proved she is back in peak form by winning the Hamar World Cup (Dec 14, 2025) with a 1:14.39. She is the most technically balanced skater in history, but she is "high variance" because she often prioritizes the 1500m and Team Pursuit, which can leave her slightly fatigued for the 1000m sprint.

The veteran and former World Record holder. She finished 4th in Hamar and 5th in Salt Lake City. While she may no longer have the top-end speed of Leerdam, her experience in managing Olympic pressure makes her a 2-star threat.

The breakout star of the North American leg. She took a stunning Bronze in Salt Lake City with a 1:12.77 and was officially named to the Canadian Olympic team 11 days ago (Jan 15). She has the "glide" and high-speed cornering that matches the elite Dutch skaters.
Japan's second-best 1000m skater. She has three top-6 finishes this winter and is the fastest "opener" in the field outside of Femke Kok.

The Defending Olympic Champion and World Record holder. Takagi won the Hamar World Cup (Dec 2025) and pushed Beune to the absolute limit in Inzell, losing by only 0.25s. She is "high variance" only because she is skating a massive program in Milan (500m through 3000m + Pursuit); if the schedule is tight, she may lack the explosive power needed for the final 300 meters.

The reigning 2025 European Allround Champion. She has been the most consistent "Silver/Bronze" threat to Beune and Takagi all season. She holds the fastest time in the world this year (1:51.71 from Salt Lake), but she has occasionally struggled on the "heavier" sea-level ice of Europe.

The endurance machine. Wiklund took Bronze in the Inzell World Cup yesterday and is the reigning World Champion in the 3000m. Her strength is her final lap; if the pace is fast enough to burn out the sprinters (like Kok or Takagi), Wiklund is the favorite to overtake them on the final crossing.

The veteran legend. She finished 5th in Inzell and 6th in the earlier Calgary World Cup. While she lacks the 1:51 speed of the top three, her "opening" is still among the fastest in the world. If she gets a favorable pairing, she could sneak onto the podium.

The "Marathon Woman." Blondin officially qualified for her third Olympics 11 days ago (Jan 15). She recently won her first 1500m World Cup medal in nearly five years, proving she has found a second wind in her career. Her tactical intelligence makes her a threat in any pair.

China's top medal hope. She took Bronze at the 2025 World Championships and finished 4th in Inzell last week. She has the most efficient cornering technique in the field and thrives in the high-pressure environment of the "Big Two" heats.
The "Norwegian Engine"; her win in Inzell yesterday proved she is the only person who can currently out-skate the Dutch on pure power.
The "New Queen"; she is the favorite to keep the 3000m gold in Dutch hands following Schouten’s retirement.
The "Clutch Performer"; she has a history of peaking perfectly for the Olympic window and is Canada's best individual medal hope.

The 2025 World Champion. She won the Hamar World Cup in December and pushed Beune to the limit at the Dutch Trials. She has the best "sprint-to-distance" transition in the world, often winning races in the final 400 meters.

The "Iron Woman" of Canada. She took Bronze in Inzell yesterday and has been on the podium in three out of five World Cups this winter. At 35, she is skating faster than she did in her 20s and is currently ranked World #3.
The surprise European Silver Medalist (Jan 9). She has made massive strides this winter and is the first Belgian woman to seriously contend for a long-track medal.

The 38-year-old legend. You can never count out the woman with six Olympic medals. She finished 4th at the European Championships two weeks ago and remains the most tactically sound skater in the pair-draw.

The "Home Hope." She took 5th at the European Championships on Jan 9. While she hasn't hit the 3:56 range this year, the "home ice" boost in Milan and her tactical experience make her a threat for a surprise bronze.
The "Norwegian Powerhouse"; she is the reigning overall Long Distance World Cup champion and is currently the only skater in the world who can hold 31-second laps for the entire 5000m.
The "Endurance Machine"; she thrives on the "heavy" sea-level ice of Milan and is looking to go one better than her Silver in Beijing.

The "Home Hero." She set an Italian National Record (6:51.07) in Calgary last year. In Milan, with the crowd behind her for the final laps of the 5000m, she could find the extra energy needed to sneak onto the podium.

The G.O.A.T. of distance skating. At 38, she is still a podium threat, having taken Bronze in the Calgary World Cup earlier this cycle. Her experience in managing the "Milan ice" (which can get heavy during long races) is superior to anyone else in the field.

The reigning Dutch 5000m Champion. She set a massive personal best (6:41.48) in November and is the fastest Dutch skater on the 5k this season. She is a specialist in the 12.5-lap grind and represents the biggest threat to a Wiklund/Weidemann 1-2 finish.
Having a career-best distance season. She took Bronze in the 3000m in Inzell two days ago and has been a top-5 fixture in the 5k all winter.

The "Sprint King." Just yesterday (Jan 25, 2026), Stolz officially defended his 500m World Cup Overall Title, winning eight medals across the season. He is currently on a trajectory to attempt an unprecedented triple gold (500m, 1000m, 1500m). He is "low variance" because even on a bad day, his technical second lap is so fast that he rarely falls off the podium.
Having a career-best season with several Bronze medals in the World Cup circuit. He is currently Poland's strongest individual medal hope in any skating discipline.

The "Dutch Rocket." He holds the World Leading Time this season (33.63) set in Salt Lake City. He pushed Stolz to the limit at the Inzell World Cup yesterday, taking Silver. He is "high variance" only because he relies on a risky, aggressive start that can occasionally lead to a "slip" in the first 100m, but on pure speed, he is the only man who has consistently beaten Stolz's times this winter.

The Beijing Bronze medalist. Morishige won the Japanese National Title (Dec 26, 2025) and has multiple podiums this winter. He is a "Big Event" specialist who excels at maintaining speed through the final turn.

The "Consistency King." The Beijing Silver medalist finished 2nd overall in the World Cup standings for the 2024/25 season and remained a top-5 fixture this winter. While he has struggled to find the "33-second" gear this month, his experience and explosive start (9.50s openers) keep him in the medal conversation.

The "Apex Predator." Stolz is the reigning three-time World Champion at this distance. Just yesterday in Inzell, he won the 1000m World Cup finale, securing the Overall Crystal Globe. He holds the fastest time in the world this season (1:05.37) and has a technical "second lap" that is consistently 0.4 seconds faster than anyone in history. Barring a fall, he is as close to a guaranteed gold as it gets in speed skating.
Having a career year. He broke the Polish national record twice this winter and is consistently hovering around the 5th–8th place mark.

The "Dutch Prodigy." After a breakout 2024 season, de Boo has cemented himself as Stolz’s primary rival. He took Silver in Inzell yesterday and is the only skater this winter to stay within half a second of Stolz at sea level. He is "high variance" because he skates a very high-risk line in the final corner, but his raw power makes him the clear favorite for Silver.
The "Phenom"; he is looking to complete the 500/1000/1500 triple. His ability to maintain a high stroke rate through the final turn is the best the sport has ever seen.
The "Veteran"; he is seeking a historic three-peat in the 1500m. He currently holds the "Mental Edge" in head-to-head pairings due to his aggressive crossing style.

The new World Cup Overall Champion. The 19-year-old’s 6:01.98 for 2nd place yesterday proved he is the most consistent skater of the 2025/26 season. He is "high variance" only because the Olympics are a different beast for a teenager, but he is the points-leader for a reason.
The man who broke the world. After yesterday's 5:58.52, he is the undisputed favorite. He isn't just winning; he's reinventing the speed required for the distance.
The former World Record holder (6:00.23 in Nov 2025). He took Bronze yesterday and is consistently in the 6:00–6:03 range. He is France's best chance for a gold medal in Milan.
Just missed the podium yesterday in 4th. He’s been remarkably consistent all year and is the engine behind the world-record-holding US Team Pursuit squad.
5th place yesterday. While he wasn't on the podium in Inzell, he is the reigning World Champion and will have the home-ice advantage. He is clearly "saving" his best for Milan.
The 39-year-old veteran finished 16th yesterday. He’s a "1" right now because his form has dipped significantly, but you can never totally count out an Olympic Champion.

The top-ranked Dutchman from yesterday (8th). Given the total collapse of the usual Dutch favorites (Roest, Bergsma), Huizinga is currently the only one showing the form necessary to even dream of a podium.

The "Wunderkind." He won the 10,000m in Heerenveen (Dec 6, 2025) with a stunning 12:29.63. He proved yesterday in Inzell that his endurance is the best in the world right now. He is "high variance" only because 25 laps under Olympic pressure is a massive mental load for a teenager.

The "World Record Holder." After his sub-6:00 performance in the 5k yesterday, it is clear he has the best "engine" in the world. However, the 10k is a different tactical animal, and Eitrem has occasionally struggled with pacing the middle 4,000 meters.

He took Bronze in the Heerenveen 10k and has been the most consistent "long-distance" threat of the year. He has a very "flat" pacing profile, meaning he doesn't slow down, which is essential for a 10k podium.

The "Titan of the 10k." While he was 5th in the 5k yesterday, he finished 2nd in the only 10k World Cup this season. He is the reigning World Champion (2025) and has centered his entire life around winning this specific gold on home ice. He is the safest bet because his technique is specifically designed for the 25-lap grind.

The "Old Guard." The 2018 Gold medalist finished 4th in the Heerenveen 10k. While he is 39, his experience in the 10,000m is deeper than anyone else's. He knows exactly how to "suffer" through the final 10 laps.

The "Undisputed Kings." They are the definition of 5-star favorites. This season, they went undefeated, winning every single World Cup race. Most importantly, on Nov 16, 2025, they shattered their own World Record with a time of 3:32.49. They are "low variance" because their synchronization is flawless; from a head-on view, they move so perfectly in sync it looks like only one skater is on the ice.

The "Home Powerhouse." Italy finished 2nd overall in the world standings and took Silver in the final World Cups. They are the 2024 World Champions and, on the heavy sea-level ice of Milan, their superior strength-skating gives them a massive advantage over the "gliders."

The "Underperforming Giants." The Dutch have struggled with their roster rotation this year, finishing 3rd in the World Cup standings. While they have the individual talent, they lack the years of chemistry that the U.S. and Norwegian teams possess. They are a podium lock, but Gold looks out of reach unless the favorites fall.
The most improved team of 2026. Led by the resurgent Loubineaud, they took a shock Silver in the Calgary World Cup and have proven they can skate sub-3:40 at altitude.
The "Challengers"; they are the only team with a "sub-6-minute" skater leading their train, giving them a terrifying final 400m.
